Unlike continuous-time survival analysis, which assumes that events can occur at any instant, discrete-time models are appropriate when events are only observed or recorded at specific time points. This approach is particularly useful where data collection occurs at regular intervals, and exact event times are unknown or impractical to measure."}]},{"type":"element","tag":"p","props":{},"children":[{"type":"text","value":"In discrete-time survival models, the hazard function‚Äî- the probability that an event occurs at a particular time interval given that it has not occurred before‚Äî- is modeled using logistic regression or other generalized linear models. The data are typically organized in a person-period format, where each individual contributes one or more observations corresponding to each time interval they are at risk. Covariates can be included to assess their effects on the hazard probability, allowing researchers to examine how factors influence the timing of events over the discrete time periods."}]},{"type":"element","tag":"p","props":{},"children":[{"type":"text","value":"By accommodating the discrete nature of time measurement, these models provide a flexible framework for analyzing survival data without the need for strong assumptions about the underlying hazard function‚Äôs form. They can handle time-varying covariates and allow for the inclusion of complex patterns of hazard probabilities across time intervals. Discrete-Time Survival Models enhance the ability to understand and predict event occurrence in longitudinal studies where time is measured in distinct units, offering valuable insights into the
